etymologies: Old English til, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse til ‘to’, also ultimately to till

notes.text: In most contexts, till and until have the same meaning and are interchangeable. The main difference is that till is generally considered to be more informal than until. Until occurs much more frequently than till in writing. In addition, until tends to be the natural choice at the beginning of a sentence: until very recently, there was still a chance of rescuing the situation. Interestingly, while it is commonly assumed that till is an abbreviated form of until (the spellings 'till and 'til reflect this), till is in fact the earlier form. Until appears to have been formed by the addition of Old Norse und (“as far as”) several hundred years after the date of the first records for till

definitions: up to (the point in time or the event mentioned); until

examples.text: I went to bed at 8 last night and slept till 6.30
she did not publish her first novel till 1915
it won't be long now till our wedding day

notes.text: In most contexts, till and until have the same meaning and are interchangeable. The main difference is that till is generally considered to be more informal than until. Until occurs much more frequently than till in writing. In addition, until tends to be the natural choice at the beginning of a sentence: until very recently, there was still a chance of rescuing the situation. Interestingly, while it is commonly assumed that till is an abbreviated form of until (the spellings 'till and 'til reflect this), till is in fact the earlier form. Until appears to have been formed by the addition of Old Norse und (“as far as”) several hundred years after the date of the first records for till

definitions: up to the point in time or the event mentioned; until

examples.text: he did not enter the town till it was nearly dark

shortDefinitions: up to point in time mentioned

etymologies: late Middle English (in the general sense ‘drawer or compartment for valuables’): of unknown origin

definitions: a cash register or drawer for money in a store, bank, or restaurant
shortDefinitions: cash register or drawer for money

phrases.text: with one's hand in the till

etymologies: Old English tilian ‘strive for, obtain by effort’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch telen ‘produce, cultivate’ and German zielen ‘aim, strive’, also ultimately to till. The current sense dates from Middle English

examples.text: no land was being tilled or crops sown

shortDefinitions: prepare and cultivate land for crops

etymologies: late 17th century (originally Scots, denoting shale): of unknown origin

definitions: a sediment consisting of particles of various sizes and deposited by melting glaciers or ice sheets.
shortDefinitions: boulder clay or other sediment deposited by melting glaciers or ice sheets
